explanation: The report is correct. The assignment earliest_deadline = 0; is executed unconditionally but has no effect on program behaviour: earliest_deadline is always given a meaningful value before any use (it is set when earliest_tmot_conn is made non-NULL from normal_timeout_tail or from the first qualifying manual_timeout_tail entry, and the only expression that references earliest_deadline is in a || where the right-hand side is only evaluated when earliest_tmot_conn is non-NULL). Removing the assignment would not change program semantics, so per MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 (any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code) this is dead code. The comment “mute compiler warning” confirms it was placed solely to silence diagnostics rather than for semantics. To comply with MISRA, initialize earliest_deadline at the point where it is actually needed (or otherwise restructure the code) instead of performing an unconditional, redundant assignment.
